comments.commentBody: I find it amazing that Republicans lost the popular vote for the presidency and the Senate in 2016, control the Federal government because of a set of undemocratic institutions (the Senate, the Electoral College) and undemocratic practices (gerrymandering, voter suppression, refusal to have a Senate vote on Merrick Garland) and claim that Americans gave a clear answer that favored their agenda.  They might not appreciate New York values, but they certainly embrace chutzpah.

"Cite jobs numbers all you want, but what does it matter if we can't even get to them without destroying our cars?"

That is called "lemon socialism", privatizing the rewards while socializing the losses:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lemon_socialism

"Socialism for the rich and capitalism for the poor" dates back to Andrew Jackson, who so-called President Trump likes to think he is channeling.

REAL socialism is inherently anti-corporate because it by the people for the people.

https://userctl.com/BlueVsRed/036.png

And don't bring up the Soviet Union or China, totalitarian states pretending to be socialistic. That is communism, not socialism.

Just ask Sweden!

The hard work of finding a healthcare solution that works for all Americans is not technical or practical, but ideological. We have Medicare. It works. It should available to all Americans. No simpler or cheaper solution has been proposed.

HR 676 is a definitive solution. Making the federal government our single payer will bring economic security to Americans and save $1 trillion annually.

How many more thousands of lives must be sacrificed on the pyre of free market ideology? Let's join the civilized world, and treat each other as human beings instead of cost centers.

Updating a previous post regarding drug testing and public assistance:
The SNAP (food stamp) program and the mortgage interest deduction both cost the federal government roughly $70 billion annually.
TANF costs the federal government $15-16 billion annually.
Cost to the federal government of the employer-sponsored health insurance deduction:
$260 BILLION A YEAR.

War on the Poor--a nice rhyming jingle for Gov. Walker (my self-correct changed his name to "Gov. Wallet"!) and his ilk.
You and all your  Republicans cronies do the bidding of whoever has the most money...what you do does not make most people's lives better, say it out loud if you need to but  your truth is a lie!
You do that, Scott.  Stand there all alone, ignoring angry citizens and peaceful protestors who happen to be voters.  Keep it up, and see where it gets the GOP.
Having read this, feel the need to wash my hands...

Take this even further: The cities can keep the money they otherwise would send to the states and federal government. The cities will become better, more attractive places to live, and everyone else can just dry up and blow away. Cities will become more and more bastions of Democratic values, and we will have our country back. I'm sorry, all you people in rural and small town Iowa and Wisconsin where I once lived. The handwriting has been on the wall for 40 years that the times were changing. You should have adapted instead of being suckered by a stupe like Trump. And I left Wisconsin ten years ago, partly because I couldn't stomach this windbag, Walker. I don't see people scrambling to move there. I am most sorry about what he has done to education in that state. I think the man is evil.
I look forward to your comments. Bang on!
Isn't this the guy who wrecked the Wisconsin economy?

What happens when the state government does not have the money. State governments are required to balance their budgets. Federal largess is essential to our country. What happens when a state has a catastrophe and it doesn't have the money. What happens then Mr. Scott?

According Walker democracy is about power. Those who have it have the unrestricted right to use it as the please. Listening to, much less conceding points to ones critics is weakness, not power. The majority rules, and the minority obeys.

There are those in Washington who argue that any checks and balances on power occur every two to four years during elections. Once the election is over, the winners have the power to govern as they please.

But what about the people? Yes, the people who according to polls say 70% want a ban on assault rifles. By almost similar rates the people want Medicare for All. The sentiment of the voter is for lower taxes, but fair taxes. Billionaire loopholes and off shore investor windfalls is not what the people have in mind.

Walkers words have nothing to do with being resolute or true to party positions. They illustrate just how broken our democracy is. Districts are drawn to limit opposition. Over 30,000 lobbyists control Washington. The 95% re-election rate for incumbents reflects the power of money, not popularity. Our local papers don't inform us of what bills are being considered, who sponsors them or what the final vote is.

These raucous district meetings are a last desperate gasp by average citizens to exercise some measure of what democracy is supposed to be, a reflection of the will of the people. Walkers response? Don't listen to them. Listen to ALEC, listen to big donors, listen to lobbyists. That's really how democracy works.
Richard, you know the answer to your question. Because people have been duped into voting against their and the country's best interest. Just look at Kansas.

Mr. Walker's argument would carry some credibility if he addressed the chronic violation of First, Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights that are routine under the governments of States that use "States Rights" as a euphemism for abuse. Is he also advocating an end to revenue sharing?  If so, New Yorkers, Californians and other economically healthy states would see further booms and tax relief while the poorer states (not sue where Wisconsin falls on this spectrum) would suffer deep deficits in education, health and security funding.  Someone needs to remind him that we are no longer living in 1776.

Walker is just 1 more neoconservative who thought it was great when the Tea Party would show up to Democrats'  town halls during the Obama administration and raise hell. Now that they're getting a dose of their own medicine (finally) they want to pass a bunch of laws to stop it which would be a blatant violation of free speech rights at public forums given by elected officials. So Walker and the rest need to shut up and take their medicine.

One of the things I have felt compelled to do since the election is keep a few dollars in my pocket for the panhandlers. When I give, I do look them in the eye and wish them luck. It's a small thing, but I think we all need to experience more kindness these days.

Recently I began to spend a lot of time in Center City Philadelphia, where there is a lot of panhandling.  Where before, I had a strict policy of not giving to people asking on the streets, I find that my position has changed.  I share the same "home" with these people and on occasion I've started giving them something.  On a certain level, they are my neighbors.  I have no illusions that this will make a difference in anyone's life, but it may get them the coffee, sandwich or whatever they think they need at that particular moment.  Trying to move away from being in judgement about what that something might be.  That's theirs to deal with.

Years ago, when I was living in NYC and troubled by the number of people asking for money, I asked myself which was worse: to give a dollar to someone who was a scammer or to walk past a person who was truly hungry when I could easily have afforded to give the dollar?

It was no contest. Out of every five dollars I give, I'd rather have four go to scammers than walk right past a truly hungry, homeless person. The latter is simply too barbaric for me.

I liked your letter and wonder if the Greeks today, after years of austerity and an enormous wave of desperate refugees, would still be so generous to a stranger in need. I hope so, although I think at some point compassion fatigue might set in.

This resonated with me. Although I'm not a Catholic (in fact, I'm an atheist), when I interact with panhandlers, I have a strong sense of there-but-for-the-grace-of-god. In fact, I'm actually homeless right now, albeit temporarily, and am so grateful that I have the means to get through this difficult time.

Respect and dignity cost nothing and they matter so much. I rarely have money to give, but I often have the extra ten seconds to stop, smile, and say, "I'm sorry, sir/ma'am, I don't have any change. Take care and good luck."

How rich (pun intended) advice on helping the homeless from a man who lives in a palace paid for mostly by poor people. Advice of connecting with the pan handler by touch from a man who is surrounded with an armed sercuriy detail. Advice from a man who leads an organization with a policy on birth control that contributes to the existence of so many poor. No thanks. When will the church sell some of its vast real estate holdings and art and do charity work with the proceeds?

The Pope is advocating acts of good will, when the impulse arises. To note that moment is to connect with ones humanity. To act on that impulse is ultimately wholesome, barring placing oneself in danger or some other common sense concern. We can never know definitively how gifts will be used, or how they will be received; thanklessness might even bring up disgruntlement. But deal with it. This what it means to be humbled.

Giving to panhandlers is not a direct fix for poverty. Admitting the similarities between “us and them” is the mental adjustment that matters. The dollar is just a token of hope between us.

Pope Francis is not afraid of the occasional imperfect consequences as long as evil is not intended. Society, religion and even the news media can be currupted by casuistic logic and misguided control.
The cards are instantly saleable on the street, often for less than face value. That $5 card nets them $4 or less to add to their drug/alcohol money.

Actually, this pope seems like an okay guy in many ways. I didn't approve of the last one, or the one before, either, but this is good advice.

I give. What I don't do is believe the stories or pretend to believe them. But I give.
